newsitem.title: USA: U.S. automakers complain about dollar strength - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: U.S. automakers complain about dollar strength - WSJ.

text.p: U.S. automakers are voicing complaints to the Clinton administration about the strength of the dollar against the Japanese yen, the Wall Street Journal said in its electronic edition on Friday.

The heads of the Big Three U.S. automakers -- Ford, Chrysler and General Motors -- told Vice President Al Gore at a meeting in Detroit they were concerned about yen weakness and the impact rising Japanese car imports could have on the U.S. economy, the paper said, citing an interview with Ford chairman Alex Trotman.
While they want Clinton to try to "talk" the dollar down, the auto industry was not looking for trade sanctions or import restrictions, Trotman was quoted as saying in an interview with the Journal.
